By Ayesha Rascoe
| GREENSBORO
column2: N.C.

column1: GREENSBORO
column2: N.C. President Barack Obama said on Tuesday that Republican presidential nominee Donald Trump's comments on a 2005 videotape about groping women would disqualify him from even a job at a convenience store.    Speaking at a campaign rally in Greensboro
column3: North Carolina
column4: for Democratic presidential nominee Hillary Clinton
column5: Obama said the choice was clear in the Nov. 8 election even before the tape was leaked last week showing Trump speaking crudely about women.""Now you find a situation in which the guy says stuff that nobody would find tolerable if they were applying for a job at 7-Eleven
column7: referring to the convenience store chain. Trump said during Sunday night's presidential debate he was embarrassed by the video
column8: but dismissed it as ""locker room talk.""

column1: Obama also criticized some Republicans who have condemned the remarks but are still backing the New York businessman.""The fact that now you've got people saying: 'We strongly disagree
column2: we really disapprove ... but we're still endorsing him.' They still think he should be president
column3: that doesn't make sense to me

column1: Earlier on Tuesday
column2: White House spokesman Josh Earnest said the remarks in the recording amounted to sexual assault. Obama also took aim at Trump's business credentials
column3: referring to a New York Times report that showed he claimed a nearly billion dollar loss in one year on his taxes in the 1990s.

column1: 1	http://reuters.com/article/us-usa-election-trump-idUSKCN12C2I5	Trump intensifies attacks on Ryan with four weeks left until Election Day	"
By Steve Holland and Emily Stephenson
| OCALA
column2: Fla./WASHINGTON

column1: OCALA
column2: Fla./WASHINGTON Republican presidential nominee Donald Trump escalated his attacks on U.S. House of Representatives Speaker Paul Ryan on Wednesday
column3: deepening a fracture in the party with only four weeks to go until the Nov. 8 election.Trump
column4: at a rally before thousands of supporters jammed into a livestock arena in Ocala
column6: also attempted to drive voters away from Democratic rival Hillary Clinton with an overwhelmingly negative speech in which he described her as corrupt and unqualified for the presidency.Ryan said on Monday he was no longer going to campaign for or defend Trump and advised House Republicans not to support the White House candidate if they did not want to. His move followed outcry over a video that surfaced last Friday showing Trump bragging in 2005 about groping women and making unwanted sexual advances.Trump's response to being abandoned by Ryan
column7: the country's most senior elected Republican
column8: has veered between saying he feels free now to campaign on his own terms and assailing Ryan and other ""disloyal"" Republicans. ""Already the Republican nominee has a massive disadvantage and especially when you have the leaders not putting their weight behind the people
column9: the New York businessman said on Wednesday
column10: complaining that Ryan and others had not called to  congratulate him on what he felt was a strong performance at a debate against Clinton on Sunday.""You'd think they'd say great going Don
column11: let's go. Let's beat this crook
column15: as the crowd booed in sympathy. ""There is a whole deal going on there. There is a whole deal going on and we're going to figure it out. I always figure things out. But there's a whole sinister deal going on.""The release of the video has plunged Trump and the Republican Party into a deep crisis that has jeopardized his chances of winning the White House
column16: when he was already lagging Clinton in national opinion polls
column17: and possibly put Republican control of the U.S. Congress in danger.

column1: WRONG FOCUS
column2: LAWMAKERS COMPLAIN

column1: Trump's fresh round of attacks came even as his campaign manager
column2: Kellyanne Conway
column3: heard concerns from some House Republicans that Trump's criticism of Ryan was distracting from his message on how to defeat Clinton and win the White House.Conway convened a conference call with House Republicans who support Trump that lasted about an hour.

column1: A congressional aide said Conway went through a list of differences between Trump and Clinton and talked about how to make the case for Trump and against Clinton.The general theme of comments from lawmakers on the call was that Trump needed to focus on his message to the United States and distinguish it from Clinton's
column2: the aide said.The aide said members specifically brought up Trump's attacks on Ryan as a distraction from that message. The tone from House Republican was one of frustration at Trump's attacks on a fellow Republican
column3: the aide said.The campaign and Conway did not respond to requests for their comments about the call.

column1: Nonetheless
column2: Ryan has been facing considerable blowback from a number of his fellow House Republicans since announcing his decision to focus on electing Republicans in Congress.Oklahoma Republican Jim Bridenstine
column3: a member of the conservative House Freedom Caucus
column4: tweeted on Wednesday that he will not support Ryan - presumably
column5: for speaker in the next Congress -- because of Ryan's failure to defend Trump.""Given the stakes of this election
column6: If Paul Ryan isn't for Trump
column7: then I'm not for Paul Ryan
column9: who called for Trump to withdraw from the race in a Saturday tweet
column10: says his position has not changed but that he will vote for all Republican candidates on the ticket including Trump.""I intend to support the nominee of our party. But he's got a lot of work to do

column15: in an interview that aired late on Tuesday.Thune was among a string of Republican officials and former officials who called on Trump to withdraw from the race over the weekend. (Additional reporting by Susan Cornwell and David Morgan in Washington; Editing by Caren Bohan and Frances Kerry)"

column1: 2	http://reuters.com/article/us-usa-election-russia-putin-idUSKCN12C1H6	Putin says U.S. hacking scandal not in Russia's interests	"

MOSCOW The scandal that erupted in the United States over allegations Russia hacked Democratic Party emails has not been in Moscow's interests and both sides in the U.S. election campaign are just using Russia to score points
column2: Vladimir Putin said on Wednesday.The U.S. government on Friday formally accused Russia for the first time of a campaign of cyber attacks against Democratic Party organizations ahead of the Nov. 8 presidential election.And the White House said on Tuesday it would consider a variety of responses to the alleged hacks.""They started this hysteria
column3: saying that this (hacking) is in Russia's interests. But this has nothing to do with Russia's interests
column4: President Putin told a business forum in Moscow. Putin said the accusations were a ploy to divert U.S. voters' attention at a time when public opinion was being manipulated.

column1: Everyone is talking about 'who did it' (the hacking)
column2: said Putin. ""But is it that important? The most important thing is what is inside this information.""The Kremlin said earlier on Wednesday it took a negative view of White House statements about a planned ""proportional"" response to the alleged cyber attacks.

column1: Putin complained that all sides in the U.S. presidential race were misusing rhetoric about Russia for their own ends
column2: but said Moscow would work with whoever won the election ""if
column3: of course
column4: the new U.S. leader wishes to work with our country"".""About a decade ago
column5: they wouldn't mention Russia at all
column6: because it was not even worth talking about
column7: such a third-rate regional power and not interesting at all. Now Russia is problem number one in the entire election campaign

column1: All they do is keep talking about us. Of course it's pleasant for us
column2: but only partly because all participants are misusing anti-Russian rhetoric and poisoning our bilateral relations.""   (Reporting by Katya Golubkova and Alexander Winning; Writing by Christian Lowe; Editing by Andrew Osborn)"

column1: 3	http://reuters.com/article/us-usa-saudi-yemen-congress-idUSKCN12C1ZW	U.S. lawmaker urges Saudi arms sales halt
column2: cites possible Yemen 'war crimes'	"

column1: WASHINGTON A U.S. lawmaker urged the Obama administration to suspend cooperation with a Saudi-led coalition conducting airstrikes in Yemen
column2: saying in a letter released on Wednesday that civilian casualties from the strikes ""appear to be the result of war crimes.""Rep. Ted Lieu
column3: a California Democrat
column4: wrote to Secretary of State John Kerry on Tuesday
column5: saying the coalition had conducted more than 70 ""unlawful airstrikes"" in Yemen.""It appears that either the Saudi coalition is intentionally targeting civilians or they are not distinguishing between civilians and military targets. Both would be war crimes
column7: who had taught classes on the law of war when he was a lawyer in the U.S. Air Force. His letter increases pressure on the White House over Yemen after the administration announced Saturday it was reviewing support to the Saudi-led coalition after an air strike killed 140 mourners at a funeral.U.S. arms sales to Riyadh and other support to the coalition should be halted until the White House review is completed

column1: Lieu also cited a Reuters article published on Monday
column2: which reported that the Obama administration went ahead with arms sales to Saudi Arabia despite some officials' fears that Washington could be implicated in war crimes for supporting the Saudi-led air campaign.The Saudi-led coalition has said it takes its responsibilities under international humanitarian law seriously
column3: and is committed to the protection of civilians in Yemen.State Department spokesman John Kirby said in a statement on Wednesday: ""We have received the letter
column4: and are aware of congressional concerns regarding arms sales to Saudi Arabia. We
column6: remain gravely concerned by the high toll of the conflict
column7: including civilian casualties and damage to infrastructure caused by all sides of the conflict.""

column1: Aid and assistance for any country are always under review and subject to modification. We are going to review our position and continue to have further policy discussions
column2: Kirby said.Several recent efforts in the U.S. Congress to halt arms sales to Saudi Arabia have failed.

column1: But the White House on Saturday announced it was initiating an ""immediate review"" of U.S. support to the Saudi-led coalition  after the apparent coalition air strike on the funeral.Saudi Arabia has said it will investigate the circumstances of that strike. (Reporting by Warren Strobel; Editing by Alistair Bell and Bernadette Baum)"

Parliamentary elections in September showed that Russians do support their government

column1: 6	http://reuters.com/article/us-usa-election-trump-un-idUSKCN12C0UE	Trump as president would pose global danger: U.N. rights chief	"
By Stephanie Nebehay
| GENEVA
GENEVA The world will be in danger if Republican nominee Donald Trump becomes president of the United States
column2: the top United Nations human rights official said on Wednesday.U.N. High Commissioner for Human Rights Zeid Ra'ad al Hussein cited Trump's views on vulnerable communities including minorities and his talk of authorizing torture in interrogations
column3: banned under international law
column4: as ""deeply unsettling and disturbing"".""If Donald Trump is elected on the basis of what he has said already - and unless that changes - I think it is without any doubt that he would be dangerous from an international point of view
column5: Zeid told a news briefing in Geneva.Trump lashed out at U.S. House Speaker Paul Ryan and other ""disloyal"" Republicans on Tuesday and vowed to campaign in whatever style he wants now that the party establishment has largely abandoned him. This occurred after a 2005 video surfaced last week showing him bragging crudely about groping women and making unwanted sexual advances.

column1: Trump has said he would immediately re-authorize the waterboarding of suspected militants if elected on Nov. 8
column2: contending that ""torture works"". U.S. President Barack Obama
column3: a Democrat
column4: signed an executive order after taking office in January 2009 that banned waterboarding and other ""enhanced interrogation techniques"". Such executive orders can be rescinded by a successor.Zeid said that he would rather not interfere in political campaigns. But when a candidate's comments pointed to a potential use of torture
column5: prohibited under the Convention against Torture
column7: or to vulnerable groups possibly losing their basic rights

column1: In a speech in The Hague last month
column2: Zeid accused Trump of spreading ""humiliating racial and religious prejudice"" and warned of a rise of populist politics that could turn violent.""I always believe that it's incumbent on leaders to lead and to lead in a way that is ethical and moral
column3: Zeid said on Wednesday
column4: when asked about Trump. ""The use of half-truths is a very clever political device. Because as every propagandist knows
column5: you allow the listener to fill in the rest.""

column1: Trump has portrayed himself as tough on national security and promised to build a wall to stop Mexican immigrant ""rapists"" from crossing the border. ""We have to be on guard to see that in the end vulnerable populations
column2: populations at risk do not again see their rights deprived because of a view that is in the ascendancy based on false premises
column3: Zeid said. (Reporting by Stephanie Nebehay; Editing by Tom Miles and Mark Heinrich)"
